sen.j: 大蜘蛛（おおぐも）は、日本の怪談、随筆、民俗資料などにある巨大なクモの怪異。
sen.e: Ogumo is a gigantic spider monster which appears in Japanese Kaidan (ghost stories), essays, folk material and so on.

sen.j: 『狗張子』『諸皐記』『耳嚢』『宿直草』などの古書に記述があり、『土蜘蛛草子』『平家物語』では土蜘蛛として知られる。
sen.e: It was mentioned in old books such as "Inu hariko" (The Toy Dog), "諸皐記," "Mimibukuro" (Ear bag), and "Tonoigusa" (Night watchman's storybook); ogumo is known as Tsuchigumo (ground spider) in "Tsuchigumo no soshi" (Tale of the ground spider) and "Heike Monogatari" (The tale of the Heike).
sen.cmt: 諸皐記－正しい読み方不明。定訳不明。
sen.e: It was mentioned in old books such as "Inu hariko" (literally, The Toy Dog), "Shoko-ki" (a collection of ghost stories originated in Tang China), "Mimibukuro" (literally, Ear bag), and "Tonoigusa" (literally, Night watchman's storybook), while in "Tsuchigumo no soshi" (Tale of the ground spider) and "Heike Monogatari" (literally, The tale of the Heike) it is known as Tsuchigumo (literally, ground spider).
sen.cmt: 用語、文脈調整。諸皐記書名は日本古典籍データベースで確認取れました。http://base1.nijl.ac.jp/infolib/meta_pub/KTGDefault.exe?DEF_XSL=default&GRP_ID=G0001401&DB_ID=G0001401KTG&IS_TYPE=meta&IS_STYLE=default 内容参考：http://hansichi.hp.infoseek.co.jp/contents/china.html
sen.e: It was mentioned in old books such as "Inu hariko" (literally, The Toy Dog), "Shoko-ki" (a collection of ghost stories originated in Tang China), "Mimibukuro" (literally, Ear bag), and "Tonoigusa" (literally, Night watchman's storybook), while in "Tsuchigumo no soshi" (Tale of the ground spider) and "Heike Monogatari" (literally, The tale of the Heike) it is known as Tsuchigumo (literally, ground spider).

sen.j: 寛文時代の怪談集『曾呂利物語』には「足高蜘の変化の事」と題し、ある山野に住む男のもとに夜、大蜘蛛が60歳ほどの老婆に化け、髪を振り乱して襲いかかり、男に刀で足を斬り落とされたという話がある。
sen.e: "Sorori Monogatari," a collection of Kaidan of Kanbun era (1661-1673), has a story titled 'The incident of huntsman spider monster': one night, Ogumo took the shape of old woman around 60-year-old and, swinging its disheveled hair, attacked a man lived in the countryside; its legs were cut off by his sword.
sen.cmt: 「足高蜘」は「足高蜘蛛」のことと解釈して訳出しました。
sen.e: "Sorori Monogatari," a collection of Kaidan of the Kanbun era (1661-1673), has a story titled 'The incident in which a huntsman spider transmuted,' the story of which is that one night the Ogumo took the shape of an old woman of around 60 years old, swinging its disheveled hair, attacked a man who lived in the countryside, and its leg was cut off by his sword.

"Sorori Monogatari," a collection of Kaidan of the Kanbun era (1661-1673), has a story titled 'The incident in which a huntsman spider transmuted,' the story of which is that one night the Ogumo took the shape of an old woman of around 60 years old, swinging its disheveled hair, attacked a man who lived in the countryside, and its leg was cut off by his sword.

sen.j: 『狗張子』によれば、京都五条烏丸で、ある山伏が大善院という寺に泊まったところ、夜更けに激しい音とともに、天井から毛むくじゃらの手がのびて山伏の顔をなでたので、刀で斬り落としたところ、翌朝には仏壇のそばに2尺8寸（約84センチメートル）の大蜘蛛の死骸があったという。
sen.e: According to "Inu hariko," when yamabushi (a mountain priest) stayed at Daizen-in Temple in Gojo Karasuma in Kyoto, there was a very loud noise late at night, and at the same time, a hairy arm stretched out from the ceiling to pass it across yamabushi's face; yamabushi cut off the arm, and the next morning, there was the dead body of Ogumo as big as about 84 cm by a Buddhist alter.
sen.cmt: 原文には「五条通」「烏丸通」とありますが、リンク先の単語のようです。ウェブで確認すると用語が「五条」「烏丸」となっており、本来はこちらの用語を使用していると思われますので、こちらを訳出しました。「2尺8寸」の記載について用語統一リストに従うと"84.30 cm" となりますが、原文に（約84センチメートル）とありますのでこちらで訳出しました。
sen.e: According to the "Inu hariko," when a yamabushi (a mountain priest) stayed at Daizen-in Temple in Gojo Karasuma, Kyoto, there was a very loud noise late at night, and at the same time, a hairy arm stretched from the ceiling and stroked yamabushi's face, so that the yamabushi cut off the arm, and the next morning there was the dead body of the Ogumo as big as about 84 cm by a Buddhist altar there.
sen.cmt: ウェブ記載に基づく修正を、原文にも施しました。文法、スペリング。
sen.e: According to the "Inu hariko," when a yamabushi (a mountain priest) stayed at Daizen-in Temple in Gojo Karasuma, Kyoto, there was a very loud noise late at night, and at the same time, a hairy arm stretched from the ceiling and stroked yamabushi's face, so that the yamabushi cut off the arm, and the next morning there was the dead body of the Ogumo as big as about 84 cm by a Buddhist altar there.

sen.j: 天保時代の『信濃奇勝録』には、大蜘蛛が人間の生気を吸って病気にさせたという話がある。
sen.e: "Shinano Kishoroku" (a topography of Shinano Province), written in Tenpo era (1830-1844), includes a story of Ogumo which sucked energy out of a human being to make him sick.
"Shinano Kishoroku" (literally, a topography of Shinano Province, which was written in the Tenpo era (1830-1844) and includes a story of the Ogumo which sucked energy out of a human to make him ill.

sen.j: 信濃国（現・長野県）下水内郡飯山に、母子2人暮しの農家があったが、息子が病気になって「蜘蛛が来る、蜘蛛が来る」と言って苦しむようになった。
sen.e: There was a farm family of mother and child, only two people living together, in Iiyama City, Shimominochi County, Shinano Province (present-day Nagano Prefecture); the son became sick and started to suffer saying, 'Spider is coming, spider is coming.'

In Iiyama, Shimominochi County, Shinano Province (present-day Nagano Prefecture), there was a farm family of the mother and the son, and when the son became ill, he began to suffer saying, 'A spider is coming, it's coming.'
sen.cmt: 文法、用語。「市」はリンク先表示につき削除のうえ、訳文を修正しました。下水内郡は明治12年以降の名称ですが、原文のまま訳しております。
sen.e: In Iiyama, Shimominochi County, Shinano Province (present-day Nagano Prefecture), there was a farm family of the mother and the son, and when the son became ill, he began to suffer saying, 'A spider is coming, it's coming.'

sen.j: 母親は蜘蛛を殺そうとしたものの、蜘蛛は病人にしか見えないらしく、祈祷にすがっても効果はなかった。
sen.e: Mother tried to kill the spider, but it seemed that only sick people could see the spider; her prayer didn't work at all.
The mother tried to kill the spider, but it seemed that only the ill son could see the spider; and her prayers did not work at all.
The mother tried to kill the spider, but it seemed that only the ill son could see the spider; and her prayers did not work at all.

sen.j: その内に息子を想う母の念の力か、次第に母にも蜘蛛が見えるようになり、寝床にいる蜘蛛を押さえつけたが、逆に蜘蛛の糸に捕えられてしまった。
sen.e: After a while, maybe because of the mother's deep worry for her son, she gradually became able to see the spider; she held the spider down in the bed, but on the contrary, she was caught in the spider's thread.

sen.j: 母の苦しむ声を耳にした近隣の人々が駆けつけ、蜘蛛を殺して母を救い出すと、それは見たこともない巨大な蜘蛛だった。
sen.e: The neighbors heard the mother's painful groan and rushed to her place and killed the spider to rescue her; it was a gigantic spider which they had never seen before.

sen.j: 息子は一命をとりとめたものの、血を吸われた上に体のあちこちの皮が剥げ、しばらくは杖無しでは歩けないほどだったという。
sen.e: Although the son managed to survive, his blood had been sucked and many parts of his skin had come off, so that he couldn't walk without a stick.
Although the son managed to survive, his blood had been sucked and many parts of his skin had come off, so that he could not walk without a stick.

sen.j: これらのようなクモの怪異の伝承は、歳を経たクモが怪しい能力を持つという俗信から生まれたものとも考えられている。
sen.e: Legends of spider monster like these are considered to come from the folk belief that old spiders acquire mysterious power.
One theory has it that these legends of spider monsters came from a folk belief that old spiders would acquire mysterious powers.
